Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Understanding Crystal Cluster Origins in Magmas Erupted from Toba Caldera, Earth's Youngest Supervolcano
Award.AbstractNarration:
Supereruptions, the most violent volcanic eruptions on Earth, are fed by magma reservoirs that contain incredibly large volumes of silica-rich magma. Crystals formed within these magmas and found in their eruptive products contain important information on the processes that lead to such devastating eruptions. This project will investigate the storage conditions and dynamics of the silicic magma reservoir that explosively erupted the voluminous Youngest Toba Tuff (YTT) 74,000 years ago and then quiescently extruded several small rhyolite lava domes at Toba Caldera (Sumatra, Indonesia). These Toba magmas contain unusual quartz crystal clusters that likely record important evidence for the development of their host magma. Quartz clusters have seldom been recognized or studied in silicic volcanic rocks from other caldera-forming magma systems, and thus the Toba quartz clusters will be examined to understand their origin and the implications they have for silicic magma evolution and eruption potential. This research will be conducted at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore under the guidance of Dr. Caroline Bouvet de Maisonneuve, an expert on the use of crystal-scale data to determine magma storage conditions and eruption dynamics.

Petrography and cathodoluminescence imaging reveal that quartz clustering is an important process affecting 40-60% of YTT and lava dome crystals. Crystallographic orientations of individual quartz ?units? within clusters will be acquired to identify potential mechanisms for cluster formation, as well as the type of environment from which they originated. Trace element analysis will be used to chemically fingerprint each unit in a given cluster to determine whether the individual units formed under similar magma conditions, and thus potentially at the same time. Results will provide important constraints on the petrological and rheological evolution and dynamics of the Toba magma reservoir and are expected to highlight a transition from pre- to post-caldera magma storage conditions and eruption potential. Toba quartz cluster features will also be compared to those reported from solidified subsurface magma bodies to provide insight on the connection between volcanic rocks and their plutonic counterparts. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to better understand the pre-eruptive evolution and dynamics of the large Toba magma reservoir that produced one of Earth’s largest volcanic eruptions just 74,000 years ago in northern Sumatra, Indonesia. Post-caldera eruption magmatism represented by lava domes in the center of Toba caldera was also investigated, as it provides insight into the evolution of the system since the paroxysmal caldera eruption. Specifically, this study explored the occurrence of quartz crystal clusters in both the explosive and effusive Toba magmas by quantitatively assessing mechanisms responsible for quartz aggregation in a silicic volcanic environment. Quartz clusters were studied using (1) electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) to determine crystallographic orientations of individual quartz units within clusters and (2) laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS) to identify trace element signatures of each unit. EBSD measurements coupled with trace element chemistry of quartz clusters allowed determination of the dominant mechanisms of cluster formation in the host magmas. These mechanisms provide important constraints on the petrological and rheological evolution of the Toba reservoir from its pre- to post-caldera stage. Results on quartz clustering in volcanic rocks are expected to yield further insights on clusters identified in silicic plutonic rocks. The outcome of this project provides a tool for scientists to investigate crystal mush models and magma chamber dynamics that influence magma evolution, which may ultimately lead to violent caldera eruptions. Thus, similar studies may improve our understanding of other active, large caldera systems around the world (e.g., Taupo Volcanic Zone, New Zealand; Yellowstone, WY; Long Valley, CA).

The project fostered international collaboration and provided training in using instrumentation and processing quantitative textural and geochemical data. It also provided professional development in a diverse research atmosphere at the Earth Observatory of Singapore (EOS). Results were disseminated through seminars and discussions at the EOS, Nanyang Technological University, National University of Singapore, and Michigan Technological University.
